awd_titl_txt: SaTC: TTP: Medium: Collaborative: RESULTS: Reverse Engineering Solutions on Ubiquitous Logic for Trustworthiness and Security
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the globalization of the integrated circuit (IC) supply chain, the reduction of manufacturing costs and the need for shorter time to market, commercial-off-the-shelf ICs are now prevalent in modern electronic systems. However, the wide usage of such components breeds major security and trust concerns. Validating the security and trustworthiness of these components is extremely challenging since the end user does not have access to the design details. Furthermore, the cost to patch hardware level design flaws and/or hardware Trojans always costs more than patching eventual software vulnerabilities.

This project develops an automated trustworthiness and security analysis framework to help end-users address their concerns by reconstructing the behavioral description of commercial-off-the-shelf ICs and analyzing such description for functionality identification and detection of design flaws and/or potentially inserted hardware Trojans and backdoors. This tool suite offers an all-in-one technology to allow engineers to quickly go from physical circuit structure/netlists to behavior/specification and validate the security and trustworthiness of any digital ICs, through data-path and state register identification, state transition graph construction and decomposition, data flow recovery, high-level behavioral design reconstruction, and whitelist- and blacklist-based functionality determination and hardware Trojan/backdoor detection. As a Transition to Practice (TTP) project, the research team is also closely collaborating with an industrial partner in developing, integrating, and validating the tool suite, so that a holistic and practice-oriented hardware security tool suite is provided for protecting the IC supply chain.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Due to the globalization of the integrated circuit (IC) supply chain, the reduction of manufacturing costs and the need for shorter time to market, commercial-off-the-shelf ICs are now prevalently being used in modern electronic systems. However, the wide usage of such components breeds major security and trust concerns. Validating the security and trustworthiness of these components is extremely challenging since the end user does not have access to the design details. Further, the cost to patch hardware level design flaws and/or hardware Trojans always cost more than software vulnerabilities.

With the above observations, this project aims at developing a comprehensive framework of netlist reverse engineering and RTL hardware Trojan detection for assuring commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) integrated circuit (IC) supply chain security. Currently there is little effort in academia and industry to use reverse engineering for security and trust analysis targeting hardware Trojans, backdoors, and possible design flaws that are the cause of security concerns; The proposed RESULTS tool suite is intended to be an all-in-one technology to allow engineers to quickly go from netlist to RTL/specification and validate the security and trustworthiness of the recovered high-level description of any COTS components. Further, golden models of the COTS IC will not be required for the proposed framework, lessening the dilemma of traditional trust analysis approaches that rely upon behavioral comparisons between golden models and the chip under authentication.

The tool suite builds the design specification based on the reconstructed circuit?s full functionality and working mechanism. The tool suite can also be used for detection and evaluation of IP piracy schemes by providing evidence regarding an alleged IP core used in SoC designs. The effectiveness of the RESULTS tool suite will be validated through the reconstruction and security validation of the full functionality in high-level descriptions for many COTS (microprocessors, microcontrollers, DSPs, and ASICs) supplied by industrial collaborators.

During the project period, the team has completed all five planned research tasks: #1: Data-path and state register identification from a flattened netlist; # 2: Circuit state transition graph building and decomposition; #3: Data flow recovery and high-level functionality reconstruction; #4: Whitelist-matching based functionality determination and unknown Trojan detection; and #5: Blacklist-matching based known hardware Trojan detection. These technical outcomes have been broadly disseminated through publications, student dissertations/theses, and publically-available resources.

The team has been working closely with the Transition to Practice (TTP) partner throughout the project period, who provided technical guidance on directing the developed RESULTS tool suite to satisfy the practical needs from the industry?s perspective, and initiating the effort to incorporate the tool suite into their specific applications. Moreover, they hired multiple students from the team as interns to facilitate tool development communication and provide students with invaluable industry experience. The TTP partner will continue to work with the team to apply for other federal funding opportunities to further develop the tool and incorporate it into more government and industrial applications.

Educational goals including curriculum development, undergraduate and graduate research activities, women and minority student recruiting, and K-12 student mentoring have been achieved. Course modules have been developed in all team universities and the research findings from this project have been incorporated. A number of undergraduate and graduate students, multiple of whom are from underrepresented groups, were recruited and worked on various research tasks. K-12 outreach activities further broadcasted hardware security concepts into the public and induced the students? interests in studying CS/CE/EE majors.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Jia Di
